text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen the dish that I am 
making today brings me right back to my childhood

was one of my favorite things as a kid because it 
is a stuffed omelet and I always felt like he was

like opening a little present especially if I 
got to it first so stuffed omelet is called kai

yudsai kai is egg and yudsai means to stuff 
so it's pretty straightforward so let's take

a look at our ingredients so for the filling I've 
got here some ground pork now you can use ground

chicken ground shrimp or you can even do crumbled 
tofu if you want to make this vegetarian I've got

some tomatoes chopped up some onions dice and 
some long beans for an extra crunchiness you

can get a little creative with the vegetables 
you can do carrot so we'll use whatever feels

right in your filling and then for aromatics I've 
got the standard Trinity of sort of like the time

your POIs we've got garlic white peppercorns and 
cilantro roots let's get started with our filling

so we're going to start by making a paste out 
of our aromatics so I've got my garlic cilantro

roots and white peppercorns ooh I think a pepper 
jumped into my hair every time I make this paste

it just smells so good and there's something 
about the combination of garlic and white pepper

and cilantro roots there's nothing like it is so 
unique to Thai cuisine oh if you can't find Sandra

roots cilantro stems would work really well just 
chop it up finely and you don't need to pound it

that's looking pretty good to me mostly a paste 
no big chunks no stringy bits we're good to go

so before we get started just a little note on the 
pork if you buy your ground pork and it comes in

this strange stringy tubular shape if I add it 
to the pan like this I will get actual odd bits

of tubular shaped pork and I don't like that it 
doesn't look natural so I like to just kind of

mash it up a little bit and if it's a little stiff 
I like to add to some of my seasoning which is soy

sauce just to moisten it there just so there's 
no more geometric shapes going on in your food

okay so I've got just out my wok here I'm going to 
turn it on medium heat you don't need super high

heat for this especially with this stove and just 
a little bit of oil now to this I'm going to add

my herb paste my garlic cilantro roots and white 
peppercorns so just cook that until the garlic is

really aromatic and the smallest bit starts to 
turn brown and it really doesn't take very long

because it is kind of a paste so I am ready I'm 
going in with my onions and my tomatoes now I want

the onions to be sweet and I want the tomatoes 
to sort of mush and disintegrate and become part

of the sauce i I'm not looking for chunks of 
tomatoes and onions however if you like crunchy

onions if you like the flavor for all onions you 
are more than welcome to just add the tomatoes

and then move the onions towards the end so what 
I'm looking for here is just for the tomatoes to

start to break down and for the onions to start 
turning just a little translucent and getting

them really nice and sweet now it's time for 
my pork or whatever proteins and the rest of my

seasoning which I've got some oyster sauce and to 
cut all the saltiness just a little bit of sugar

okay now that looks really good I'm gonna add my 
long beans now and I'm saving the long beans into

the end because I like the crunchiness that they 
have that they give to the fish I think I'm done

this is a really nice level of moisture you 
can sort of the juice of the tomato is kind

of dispersed all over it's not dry but it's also 
not cooling with liquid that's where I want to be

yes all right now is the fun part it's making 
the egg which is the most challenging part of

this whole thing so I've got a 12 inch flat 
saute pan I'm going to turn this on about

medium heat and I'm going to coat the pan with 
pretty generous amount of oil and I like to use

just the silicone brush and brush it to make 
sure I get it gets evenly coated now you've got

a really good non-stick pan you may not need this 
much oil hey while that's heating I have two eggs

here so for the amount that I'm making two eggs 
on a 12-inch skillet is perfect and I'm going to

beat this until there are no more white gloopy 
bit and I'm going to season this egg with just

a little bit of fish sauce so this is very much 
like my tie omelet episode remember my kite Co

or Thai omelette episode just a little bit of fish 
sauce just to season the egg so the eggs not bland

all righty yeah there we go and now I'm going to 
swirl the pan swirl the pan to make a large thin

omelette and with a 12-inch skillet I like to kind 
of put it push it up the sides a little bit to get

it nice and big the big it is the easier it is 
to rap and then I just kind of move the pan to

make sure that everything is heated evenly now 
there's a fine line between the egg being too

thin and the egg being too thick most of the 
time the problem is in the egg being too thick

because it's really hard to fold a thick piece 
of omelet but if it's too thin then it tastes

kind of rubbery and not very good run the spatula 
along the edges to sort of release it take it off

heat if you're taking a bit of time okay good I 
do want some golden brown color going on because

that's really beautiful unlike French omelette 
where they're looking for yellow and no brown

Thai people like a little bit of brownie okay 
so this is dry it looks a bit darker but it's

dry so I'm going to turn off the heat because I 
do not want this to cook any further check that

it's loose yes it's loose it's got nice brown 
color going on now I am going to add my filling

I'm going to put everything except I'm going 
to save about a couple tablespoons you'll see

why in a minute and I am going to fold this way 
careful it's hot this way now if you are not good

with touching hot things you can transfer the 
egg onto a plate and do this on the plate you

don't have to do this in the pan like I'm doing 
here but oh well who to take this off you take

your serving plate you put it on in the center and 
then you just flip quickly one two three Cup tada

there's your egg so you can serve the egg close 
like this and then get the especially you've got

kids around they might want to be the one to open 
the package that's what I wanted to do but to make

it a little more elegant I like to give people a 
little sneak preview so I just take a sharp pair

a knife and cut across open and because we put a 
plate smack on it to flip it open it's a little

flat that's why I like to save this extra filling 
so I can add some volume and dimension to it at

the end so I just open it I put the rest of my 
filling in gosh this smells so good and by the

way there's no chili no spicy anything in here 
so this is a great dish to introduce your kids

to Thai food but now I've got some volume and 
height perfect I like you can leave it open

like this but I like to close it back and now 
we've got a little bit of height you can see

the filling a little bit better so I've got to 
some red bell pepper here that I finly julienned

in there some cilantro sprigs Wow and that right 
there is a showstopper look at that you bring this

to the table and people are just gonna oh and 
uh and you are gonna win some brownie points my

friends now serve this always always with jasmine 
rice but I am going to eat it just like this woo

the egg is nice and tender and that's another 
you do not want to overcook the egg because it

becomes kind of dry and rubbery so the oil helps 
moisten the egg and just as soon as the egg is

dry that's when you want to turn off your heat 
hmm super tender egg and the fillings just got

the right balance of saltiness and sweetness and 
a little bit of acidity from the tomatoes gosh

every time I eat this it just brings me right 
back I mean literally this was the coolest food

in my chopped childhood self opinion is just 
so cool to see things wrapped up in a package

and when sometimes if my tomato is not very acidic 
I like to add just a teaspoon or so of tamarind

juice just to brighten it up a little bit so when 
you taste your filling you can make that judgment

call as well so I hope you give this a try and if 
you're intimidated by the whole wrapping thing you

don't have to wrap it roll it fold it in half do 
whatever you need my first one didn't look like

that I'll tell you so when you have given this 
a try let me know how it goes either through

Facebook Twitter or Instagram please send me a 
photo I always love seeing your photos and the

recipe is as always on hot eye-catching calm if 
you enjoy the show please click to subscribe so

I can keep doing this show for you and I will 
see you next time for your next delicious type
